dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My fatherВ’s name was John Kinsella. A faded, sepia shot of a dirty little kid on a farm.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ItВ’s an Irish name. He was born in North Dakota, in 1896... Young man in doughboy uniform.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...and never saw a big city until he came back from France in 1918. Chicago. Tenement. Comiskey Park. Ballgames.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He settled in Chicago, where he quickly learned to live and die with the White Sox. Died a little when they lost the 1919 World Series... Newspaper headlines. Photo of Shoeless Joe Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...died a lot the following summer when eight members of the team were accused of throwing that Series. Dad (a catcher) playing ball. At work. Weeding.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He played in the minors for a year or two, but nothing ever came of it. Moved to Brooklyn in В’35, married Mom in В’38, and was already an old man working at the Naval Yards when I was born in 1949. Ray as an infant. With his father. In front of Ebbets Fie in miniature Dodger uniform, etc.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My nameВ’s Ray Kinsella. Mom died when I was three, and I suppose Dad did the best he could. Instead of Mother Goose, I was put to bed at night to stories of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 1 CONTINUED RAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig...and the great Shoeless Joe Jackson. Dad was a Yankees fan then, so of course I rooted for Brooklyn. But in '58 the Dodgers moved away, so we had to find other things to fight about. We did. And when it came time to go to college, I picked the farthest one from home I could find. Berkeley in the 1960s: hippies, protesters, etc.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This, of course, drove him right up the wail, which I suppose was the point. Officially my major was English, but really it was the Sixties. Ray looking foolish in long hair and tie-dye.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I marched, I smoked some grass, I tried to like sitar music... and I met Annie. Annie: blue jeans, T-shirt, freckles. Their courtship.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The only thing we had in common was that she came from Iowa and I had once heard of Iowa. We moved in together. After graduation, we moved to the Midwest, and stayed with her family as long as we could. Unsmiling American Gothic types.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Almost a full afternoon. The apartment, Ray at different jobs, the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We rented an apartment and I took a job selling insurance. I also drove a cab and worked in a pizza parlor. Dad died in June of 1 74. Annie and I got married that fail. Baby pictures.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A few years later Karin was born. She smelled weird, but we loved her anyway. Then Annie got the crazy idea that she could talk me into buying a farm. CONTINUED     3 1 CONTINUED (2) 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, Annie, and four-year-old Karin by the "SOLD" sign of their farm. Ray in a cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm thirty-eight years old and I'm about to become a farmer. I love my family, I love baseball, and I miss New York. Moving in on Ray's face.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But until I heard The Voice...I'd never done a crazy thing in my whole life. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dusk on a spring evening. The sky is a robin's-egg blue, and the wind is soft as a day-old chick. Ray Kinsella is working in the cornfield when a voice -- like that of a public address announcer -- speaks to him. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' Ray looks up and around, but sees nothing that could be t source of this sound. All around him are empty fields. He stands quietly for a few moments, then goes back to work. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' Ray jerks his head in all directions to see where this voice is coming from, but again, he sees nothing unusual -- just the furrowed fields and a few hundred feet away, the massive old farmhouse with a sagging veranda on three sides. On the north veranda is a wooden porch swing where Annie and Karin sit, sipping lemonade and dreaming. RAY (CALLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, what was that? ANNIE (CALLS BACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was what? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That voice. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What voice? CONTINUED     4 2 CONTINUED 2 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now. Like an announcement. Annie confers briefly with Karin, then calls back to Ray. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't hear anything. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Ray thinks for a second, then shakes it off, trying to dislodge that thought from his mind, and gets back to wor THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' Again, he bolts upright and looks around. Again, he sees nothing. This is beginning to bug him. He calls: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you must've heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Karin lock at each other and exchange a shrug. Annie extends her arms palms upward, and calls to Ray. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Come on. Dinner. Annie leads Karin inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks all around him with an "Okay, fellas, what's th joke?" look on his face. But there is no one there. He puts down his tools and walks toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray enters, looks at his wife skeptically and joins his wife and daughter setting the table. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there like a sound truck on the highway, or something? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nape. CONTINUED     5 5 CONTINUED 5 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids with a radio? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. You really hearing voices? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. God? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like a. . .ballpark announcer. Annie shoots him an "Are you kidding?" look. Ray responds with a shrug. They sit down to eat. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd it say? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build. it, he will come.' ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you build what, who will come? RAY (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, I hate it when that happens. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are snuggled together, asleep. All is quiet. Then: THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' Ray's eyes pop open. He looks at Annie, who does not stir Without moving, he looks around the room. There is no one there. Very quietly, he crosses to the window and looks out. He whispers out toward the cornfield: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Build what? For who? CONTINUED     6 6 CONTINUED 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind him, Annie stirs. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, honey, I'm just-talking to the cornfield. He sighs and goes back to bed. Annie cuddles up to him. Her eyes are closed, but Ray's eyes remain open. He is puzzled and concerned. CUT TO 7 TELEVISION SCREEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scene from the 1950 movie Harvey, in which James Stewar insists he is conversing with an invisible rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: RAY AND ANNIE'S KITCHEN MORNING
dialogues.text: L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ittle Karin is watching Harvey while she eats her breakfast. Ray enters, looking like he had very little sleep, and promptly turns the TV set off. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you do that? It was funny. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, Karin, it's not funny. The man is sick. He's very sick. Annie enters, putting on her coat. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin, if you're finished, get your coat and school bag. Let's go. Karin bolts from the table. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh honey, I'll take her today. I'v-e got some errands in town. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far out. She takes off her coat and kisses Ray as he takes-the car keys and heads outside. Annie sits at the kitchen table. CONTINUED     7 CONTINUED 8 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if the voice calls while you're gone? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a message. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. He exits. She grins, turns on the TV and watches Harvey. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's car pulls up, Karin runs out and Ray drives off. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is plugged into some weird-looking contraption, havin his hearing examined. Then the Doctor shines a penlight into his eyes, shrugs, and starts putting his gear away. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't find anything wrong. I could recommend a shrink, but hey, people hear things all the time. I heard a voice once. I was still living with my parents, 'then. They worked in the circus, so I was raised in the circus, and I was training to be a clown. This one day, I'm putting on my little red nose and I hear a voice, tells me to go to medical school. Here I am. Ray is not sure if he should ignore this or run. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: FARM SUPPLY STORE
dialogues.text: Farmers are loading up with seed, fertilizer, and other farmer stuff. This is the kind of place where people also linger to exchange gossip, swap lies, and pass the time. Ray is off to one side, chewing the fat with an old-timer CONTINUED     8 11 CONTINUED 11 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all those years, did you ever... (SEARCHES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard that sometimes farmers out in the field...hear things. Voices. OLD-TIMER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hearing voices? RAY (QUICKLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's just that I heard some farmers do, and... I, of course, don't, so I was wondering if I was doing something wrong, or something. Did you ever hear voices out there? CASHIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls from her CASH REGISTER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's hearing voices? OLD-TIMER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is. Out in the fields. Now, everyone in the store turns to look at Ray. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, I'm not. Really. But the people still stare. Ray addresses them. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noises! That darn tractor, it's... (forces a nervous LAUGH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll just get some 3-in-1 oil, that should... (TO THE OLD-TIMER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice talking to you. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S FARM
dialogues.text: Ray is out in the fields again, hard at work. A breeze picks up. He stops fora moment, cocks an ear and looks around. All he sees are the empty fields. Insects make the only sounds. He goes back to work. Then: THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' CONTINUED     9 12 CONTINUED 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws his tools down angrily and looks all around, bu there is no apparent source of the voice. Ray is pissed. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, who are you, and what the hell do you want from me?!? All he hears is a faraway echo. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'If you build it, he will come.' This is serious. Ray shakes his head and repeats the word to himself. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you build it... As he thinks about these words,,some unexplained impulse causes Ray to turn his head deliberately toward a portion of the cornfield between him and the house. FLASH CUT 1

dialogues.speaker: A BASEBALL FIELD L3
dialogues.text: For the briefest of moments, the dreamlike image of a baseball field at night, illuminated by floodlights, flar in over the lawn. Standing on the edge of the field, is the figure of a man with his back to us. Before we can se anything else, the image disappears. 14 RAY 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's eyes widen. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . he will come'. FLASH CUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i5 THE MAN AND THE FIELD 1 5 The dream image flares in again, this time closer to the man. He stands in the middle distance, silhouetted by the lights, and we see he is wearing a uniform of some kind. He starts to turn slowly towards us, but before we can se his face, the image disappears.     10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's mouth opens. He half-laughs, as if to say "This can't be." But whatever is in his mind won't go away. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .he will come. FLASH CUT 17 THE MAN 17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see him in head-and-shoulders. He has the muscular neck of an athlete. As he slowly turns we start to see a bit of his weathered face before the image flares out. 18 RAY 18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheels are turning inside his head. He is trying to figur all this out. In the distance, a bell is ringing. He looks O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is on the veranda ringing the dinner bell hanging b the front door. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Ray! Food!

dialogues.speaker: HER POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: We see Ray emerge slowly from the fields, the twilit sky changing colors behind him. 21 THE VERANDA 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie leans against a post, lazily watching Ray approach. She likes how he moves, and how he looks. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, cutie. Ray climbs up the steps, accepts her kiss, and instead of following her into the house, pulls her down with him ont the swing. He takes-her hand and looks into her eyes. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie... CONTINUED     11 21 CONTINUED 21 ANNIE (PLAYING ALONG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray... RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to believe this... ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the voice again. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, this gets better, I just saw a vision. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God. An actual vision. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to burn you at the stake if this keeps up. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: family is eating dinner. Ray seems lostin thought. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you don't suppose this could be like an acid flashback, do you? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never took acid. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you will someday, and it's a flash forward. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, there's more. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're subscribing to the Enquirer. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know what 'If you build it, he will come' means. CONTINUED     12 22 CONTINUED 22 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, why do I not think this is a good thing? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it means if I build a baseball field out there, Shoeless Joe Jackson will get to come back and play ball again. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. She whistles. This is serious. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Annie are putting little Karin to bed. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I thought my family was crazy, but this...this is the craziest thing I've ever heard. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's totally nuts. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, Shoeless Joe, he's... RAY (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Died in '51. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's the one they suspended, right? -AY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still dead? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far as I know. CUT TO     13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Annie in their pajamas, brushing their teeth, getting ready for bed. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what amazes me? No one could ever get you to believe in astrology, or ESP, or reincarnation, or heaven, or any of that stuff. But this...I think this shows real personal growth, Ray. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Annie smiles, but sees that Ray is troubled. She hugs him ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetie. I hope you know that even though I make jokes, I'm going to visit you every month wherever they put you. He offers her a weak smile and exits. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark. For a few seconds it is quiet. Then: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know Babe Ruth copied his swing? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did, I'd forgotten it. Ray sits up in the dark. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always felt cheated I never got to see him play. He was supposed to be so graceful, and agile. So to actually get to see him play again...to let him play again, to right an old wrong... He shakes his head in wonder just to think of it. Annie turns on the light. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Bosco. Are you actually thinking of doing this? CONTINUED     14 25 CONTINUED 25 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I can't think of one good reason why I should,-but... (takes a breath) I'm thirty-eight years old, I have a wife, a child, and a mortgage, and I'm scared to death I'm turning into my father. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your father got to do with this? Ray tries to picture his father in his mind. He speaks softly, but the words obviously have a great deal of meaning for him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never forgave him for getting old. By the time he'was as old as I am now, he was ancient. He must have had dreams, but he never did anything about them. For all I know, he may have even heard voices, too, but he sure didn't listen to them. The man never did one spontaneous thing in all the years I knew him. Annie, I'm scared that that's what growing up means. I'm afraid of that happening to me. And something tells me this may be my last chance to do something about it. (looks at her) I want to build that field. Do you think I'm crazy? She looks at him with great understanding. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He smiles wanly. She touches his face lovingly. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also think that if you feel you really have to do this... then you should do it. They hold each other's gaze, and Ray cannot remember when he has loved her so much. He takes her in his arms. Outside their window, the field of corn lies waiting. CUT TO     15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalks of corn wave slowly in the breeze. A bee buzzes near one. The light is yellow. Suddenly, the stalks bend violently to the ground as Ray's tractor plows them under

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TRACTOR 27
dialogues.text: Ray drives, Karin rides shotgun, holding the large detail diagram Ray has drawn of the ballpark's dimensions. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty Cobb called him the greatest left fielder of all time. His glove was called 'the place where triples go to die.' 28 HIGH ANGLE 28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tractor turns to plow under more corn, and we can see the size of the area Ray has staked off with marker stick

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Could he hit?

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Lifetime 356 average. Third highest in history. Karin whistles. 29 ANOTHER ANGLE 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the side of the road, an old man and woman stand and watch these neighbors-plow under their. corn. They look a each other as if to say "Could it be Communists?"

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why'd they called him Shoeless Joe?

dialogues.speaker: SEEDING THE FIELD
dialogues.text: It is days later, an area the size of a baseball field ha been plowed under, and Ray is seeding it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When he was still in the minors, he bought a new pair of spikes and they hurt his feet. About the sixth inning he took them off and played the outfield in just his socks. The other players kidded him, called him Shoeless Joe, and the name stuck.     16

dialogues.speaker: WATERING THE GRASS
dialogues.text: We can see roughly where the grass has been planted, and where the dirt will be smoothed out for the base paths. Ray stands stock-still in the moonlight, water hose in hand, patiently misting the baby grass, little Karin at h side.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then in 1919, his team, the Chicago White Sox, threw the World Series.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What's 'threw'?

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They lost it on purpose. Gamblers paid them to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, dozens of families stand to watch silent and dumb-eyed, at what has obviously become a daily spectacle among the townspeople. Some snap photos.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Except Shoeless Joe.

dialogues.speaker: SMOOTHING OUT THE FIELD
dialogues.text: Ray smooths out the base paths with a large roller, as Annie and Karin follow behind with rakes. On either side of the base paths, the infield and outfield grass is growing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nobody could prove anything one way or another, but he was the one guy who probably wasn't in on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, Annie and Karin wait as the cashier totals up their load of lumber and hardware. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean if he was supposed to be throwing it, how do you explain the fact he hit 375 for the series and didn't commit one error? Huh? KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. CONTINUED     17

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 34,
dialogues.text: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve hits, including the series' only home run. And they said he was trying to lose! KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous. CASHIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 855 dollars, sixty-four cents. From O.S., we hear oooh. Ray turns and notices for the first time that a crowd of spectators -- employees and customers -- has been watching him and whispering among themselves. They look at him as if he had two heads. Ray turns his attention back to writing a check for his purchases. He deadpans to Annie: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better notify Mars to send us more money. ANNIE (EQUALLY DEADPAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remlak won't like that. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his problem. And tell him to make it in Earth dollars this time. Ray hands over the check to the open-mouthed cashier. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Have a nice day. Ray and Annie turn and leave with Karin. The farmers watch, obviously trying hard to figure this one out. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING THE OUTFIELD WALL
dialogues.text: Ray hammers the braces that will support the outfield wal Karin hands him nails from a bag she wears around her nec

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's a famous story about when he came out of the courtroom, a kid ran up to him, tugged his sleeve and said 'Say it ain't so, Joe.' And Jackson looked down t him and said 'I'm afraid it is, kid.' CONTINUED     18 35 CONTINUED 35 KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING THE BLEACHERS 36
dialogues.text: Annie helps Ray lift a board to what will be the top row. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commissioner of Baseball suspended eight of the players -- including the great Shoeless Joe Jackson -- for life. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's suspend? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They never let him play the game again. They continue to work in silence. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray writes a check for his purchases: bats, balls, bases pitcher's rubber, home plate, etc. He appears slightly annoyed that once again, he is being stared at by all the uniformed employees of the store. He turns to catch the Store Owner staring at him the most intently. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. What! STORE OWNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the fella that plowed under your corn and built a baseball diamond, right? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What about it? STORE OWNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his hand) Greatest damn thing I ever heard. The other employees beam their agreement. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At these prices, I'm not surprised. CONTINUED     19 37 CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels his shopping cart of sporting goods out through a gauntlet of approving salesmen. They smile and pat him on the back. Ray cannot decide if they're crazier than he is. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...thank you... CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: THE LIGHT STANDARD
dialogues.text: Atop the aluminum-painted poles, an array of store-bought floodlights switch on, flaring against the blue-black sky In this sharp white light the grass glows parrot green, cool as mint, soft as a cashmere blanket. Annie and Karin watch as Ray puts down the clean white bases, which pick up the light like little moons on a cold, clear night. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father said he saw him years later playing under a made-up name in some tenth-rate league in Carolina. He'd put on fifty pounds, and the spring was gone from his step, but he could still hit. Dad used to say no one could hit like Shoeless Joe. Ray is smiling wistfully. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first time I've ever seen you smile as you mentioned your father. Ray considers that. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you. Bed time. Annie hoists Karin on her shoulders with a grunt, and the three climb their way down the bleachers. Ray's hand steadies Annie as she takes one of the steps. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful... Moonl ight butters the Iowa night. They walk along the si of the field, and Ray stops. He looks at the field. CONTINUED     20 38 CONTINUED 38 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have just created something totally illogical. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like about it. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I completely nuts? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not completely. She looks out over the baseball field. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good baseball field, Ray. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is kinda pretty, isn't it? Annie smiles at him and carries Karin inside. Ray steps onto the porch and flicks the switch shutting off the floodlights over the field. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: RAY AND ANNIE'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Annie opens her eyes and sees Ray not beside her in bed, but in th window seat, looking out at the empty field. Barely awake, she gets out of bed, shuffles to his side a curls up against him. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sign? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's going to happen out there. I can feel it. Annie lowers her head against his chest and goes back to sleep. Outside, the trees are fully leafed. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: The trees are almost bare now, and there's a Halloween pumpkin in the front window of the house. The cornstalks CONTINUED     21 40 CONTINUED 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ,rustle like crumpling paper in the Indian-summer breeze which blows fallen leaves across the empty baseball field while Ray sits in the stands... waiting. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: THE BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: it is covered with snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks forlornly out the living room window towards hi snow-covered baseball field, the merrily blinking lights of the Christmas tree behind him belying his true mood. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGTIME
dialogues.text: A baby robin tries to pull a worm out of the around. Inside the house, Annie is doing spring cleaning. She looks out the window to see:

dialogues.speaker: THE BASEBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: Ray mowing the outfield grass. He stops, looks around, listens, hears nothing, and continues mowing. 45 ANNIE 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: just watches him. CUT TO 46 TV SCREEN 46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the first exhibition game of spring training from Florida, as the announcer talks about a "southpaw" pitche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Karin watches the TV, while Annie and Ray sit at t living room table, financial ledgers spread out before th as they struggle with their accounts. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, what's a southpaw? CONTINUED     22 47 CONTINUED 47 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A left-handed pitcher. (TO ANNIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, given how much less acreage we have for corn, I'd say we'll probably .almost break even. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've spent all our savings on that field.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy.. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Karin. (TO ANNIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you saying? We can't keep the field? ANNIE (SADLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes it real hard to keep the farm, Ray. Ray closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy... RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little testy) In a minute, Karin.

dialogues.speaker: KARIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: There's a man out there on your lawn. Ray opens his eyes and turns to see Karin kneeling on the kitchen counter, looking out the window. Ray and Annie exchange a quick glance, and Ray walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seen from outside, as Ray's head appears and looks out. He sees something out there and just looks at it.     23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a Man standing on the edge ofthebaseballfield. Hi es wearing a baseball uniform. Anold-fashionedone. 50 INT HOUSE 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns to Annie. She looks out and nods thoughtfully. Annie stays very calm in emergencies. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll put up some coffee. You go ahead. Ray takes a breath and steps out onto the veranda. The night sky seems close enough to touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the porch wall, Ray finds the switch, holds his breath flicks it and the floodlights sputter to life. 52 THE MAN 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: steps onto the field. On his uniform is a large "S" with an "O" in the top crook, an "X" in the bottom, and an American flag with forty-eight stars on his left sleeve. 53 RAY 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walks through the swirling ground mist toward the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving closer to the field we see the Man standing out in left field. Feet spread wide, body bent forward from the waist, hands on hips, he waits. 55 RAY 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's mouth is dry. He reaches home plate and picks up on of the bats lying beside the pail of hard balls. The back of his neck tingles. Then, he picks up one of the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man spreads his feet, pounds his small, old-style glove, and waits to field the ball.     24

dialogues.speaker: AT HOME PLATE 57
dialogues.text: Ray tosses the ball a few feet into the air and swings at it. And misses. His face reddens, he clears his throat, and tries again. This time he connects. 58 THE FIELD 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has hit a grounder that would be easily fielded by a shortstop had there been one, but it bounces through and falls into left field. The Man runs in for it, scoops it up cleanly and throws it back to the plate. Ray is thrilled. He hits another ground ball, and this too, is fielded cleanly. Then another, which the Man deftly short-hops. Ray hollers out to him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the field play? THE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good. The ball bounces true. Ray smiles with pride. He tosses up another ball, gives it his best swing, and is thrilled to see he has actually lofted one into the air. But into center field. The Man sprints across the outfield, and makes a lovely catch in short center. Instead of throwing the ball in, the Man runs it in, loping toward home plate. Ray's heart thumps. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. The Man nods at him, takes the bat, and tests it to feel its weight. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Kinsella. THE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Jackson. Ray is thrilled to hear the words spoken. It is Shoeless Joe Jackson after all, who stands not five feet away from him, trying out all the bats now. Ray isn't quite sure if he should talk, or ask questions, or just stand there. Finally, he can't help himself. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet its good to be playing again, huh? SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like having part of me amputated. CONTINUED     25 58 CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe looks over at Ray, now, his dark eyes evincing the pa his steady voice tries to conceal. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard that old man wake up and scratch itchy legs that've been dust for fifty years. That was me. I'd wake up in the night with the smell of the ballpark in my nose and the cool of the grass on my feet. The thrill of the grass... He has found the bat he likes. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you pitch? RAY (WITH FALSE MODESTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm not bad. Joe hands Ray the bucket of balls. Ray can barely contain his excitement as he races to the mound. He stands on the rubber and faces Joe at the plate. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we need a catcher? SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you can get it near the plate, we don't. Ray smiles, takes a breath and starts his windup, during which he says aloud to himself: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am pitching to Shoeless Joe Jackson. He makes a pitch. It's not a very good one, and Joe has to step across the plate to make contact, but his swing i graceful, compact and effortlessly powerful. He drives th ball against the fence. Ray watches it with wonder and when he turns back, Jackso is gesturing with the bat for him to make the next pitch. Ray makes the standard pitcher's gesture for a curve ball RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if you can hit my curve. В°He goes into an elaborate windup, throws it, it does no curve much, and Jackson whistles it right by Ray's ear. CONTINUED     26 58 CONTINUED (2) 58 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he can hit the curve. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick with fast balls, kid. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. Ray makes another pitch, and Jackson hits a line drive do the third base line. Then a smoker down the first base line. Ray is mightily impressed. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, this feels good. Put it right here, huh? Joe holds the bat out low over the plate and Ray pitches it reasonably close to that spot. Jackson hits it out of the park, and beams. Ray brightens up with remembrance. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, you were a low ball hitter. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man, I did love this game. You know, I'd have played for food money. it was the game, the sounds, the smells. You ever held a glove or a ball to your face? Ray smiles as he walks in from the mound. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it was riding the trains from town to town. And the hotels with brass spittoons in the lobbies and brass beds in the rooms. And it was the crowd getting to their feet when the ball was hit deep. Shoot, I'd have played for free. The sound of a screen door turns their. attention to the house. Annie and Karin are coming out to them. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family. Jackson nods and then points to the floodlights. CONTINUED     27 58 CONTINUED (3) 58 SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the lights? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "All the stadiums have them now except Wrigley Field. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes it harder to see the ball. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owners found that more people could attend night games. SHOELESS JOE (SHAKES HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owners... By now, Annie and Karin have joined them. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jackson: my wife Annie, my daughter Karin. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe. Ma'm... (SHAKES ANNIE'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hand and winks AT KARIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a ghost? Ray and Annie are instantly embarrassed, and try to cover with forced, nervous laughter. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin... (to Shoeless Joe) She's just kidding. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. (TO KARIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? KARIN-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look real to me. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I guess I'm real. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to come inside'? CONTINUED     28 58 CONTINUED (4) 58 SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thanks, but...I don't think I can. Ray and Annie look at Joe for a moment, not quite understanding the ground rules here. Joe senses their discomfort and changes the subject. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, can I come back again? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I built this for you. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are others, you know. There were eight of us. It'd sure mean a lot to them. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh man, anytime. They're all welcome here. Joe looks out over the field in eager anticipation of the good times to come. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ray. I appreciate it. See you later, huh? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. See you later. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it ain't so, Joe! Joe laughs and walks to the outfield. Annie puts her arm around Ray and snuggles her head against his chest. Nearby, brook water splashes softly in the darkness, a fr shrills, and fireflies dazzle the night. Joe is in the outfield grass now, walking toward a door c into the fence. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's he going? RAY (SMILING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through that door in the fence. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when is there a door in the fence? CONTINUED     29 58 CONTINUED RAY (SMILING EVEN MORE BROADLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I didn't put one there. Joe reaches the door, opens it, and turns back to Ray, hi voice carrying effortlessly through the night air. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Is this heaven? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's Iowa. Shoeless Joe Jackson nods and fades away as he walks through the door in the fence. Ray and Annie looks at eac other in absolute wonder. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're keeping this field. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your ass we are. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to lose your farm, pal. It is Sunday afternoon, and Annie's family is visiting. her mother, pink-faced and white-dentured, sits ramrod straight in an antique rocking chair. Also present are he brother, Mark, and his wife Dee. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's so big. How can you lose something so big? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You misplaced the house once. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it turned up two days later, didn't it? MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, this stupid baseball field is going to bankrupt you. Everybody knows it. All I'm saying is if you wait till you default on your loan, you lose everything. Sell now, my partners'll (MORE) CONTINUED     30 59 CONTINUED 59 MARK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: give you a more than a fair price and you walk away with a nest egg. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mark, but no. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you holding on to this place for? You've never even liked Iowa. You don't like farming, you don't know the first thing about it --- RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey; I know a lot more about farming than you think. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you plow under your major crop? RAY (TO ANNIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a crop? Karin enters breathlessly. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, the baseball game is on. Ray beams. Karin returns the smile and reaches her arms out to be picked up. She scissors her legs around her father at belt level, hugging his neck. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us. He exits, carrying Karin. Mark shakes his head. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this guy. I'm trying to bail him out and he goes off to watch television. Annie stifles a laugh. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to be so normal. MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he beat you? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??? CONTINUED     31 59 CONTINUED (2) 59 MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drinking, right? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't drink, and he doesn't beat me, okay? Now I'll grant you, he has gotten me to worship Satan with him, but just a little. Her mother gasps. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kidding... I'm kidding! Her family has no sense of humor about this whatsoever. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we need more cheese. She goes into the kitchen, and when she has rounded the corner, she raises her eyes to heaven and mutters: ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families. 60 THE FIELD 6 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin and Ray sit on the bleachers, eating peanuts while Shoeless Joe and his seven teammates practice. (Three, including Shoeless Joe, are in the outfield, two more in the infield, one pitches, one catches, and one bats.) The men are all in their twenties or thirties, but show t sheer enjoyment of returning after an absence of sixty-fi years to the game they love. Ray directs Karin's attention to the left fielder. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch Joe. Watch his feet as the pitcher gets the sign and starts to pitch. A good left fielder knows what pitch is coming, and he can tell from the.angle of the bat where the ball's going to be hit. At the sharp crack of the bat Shoeless Joe whirls, takes five loping strides toward the fence, turns again', reach up, and the ball smacks into his glove. Karin cheers. One of the players good-naturedly boos. HAPPY FELSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showoff! CONTINUED     32 60 CONTINUED 60 BUCK WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, stick it in your ear, Felsch. EDDIE CICOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you'd run like that against Detroit I'da won twenty games that year. HAPPY FELSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for Pete's sake, that was sixty-five years ago! Give it up, will ya... SWEDE RISBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey., you guys wanna play ball, or what? HAPPY FELSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .you muscle-bound jerk. EDDIE CICOTTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? At least I got muscles. HAPPY FELSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. At most you got muscles. BUCK WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, asshole, pitch! The good-natured banter stops short, and the other player glare at Weaver who looks sheepishly toward the little gi and her father in the bleachers. BUCK WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, kid. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay! PLAYERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right,'Karin! The players resume their practicing and ribbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie emerges with-her Mother, Mark and Dee, walking towa the bleachers where Karin and Ray are still watching the spirited practice. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray? Mom's leaving. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, it was...you know, thanks for coming. CONTINUED     33 61 CONTINUED 61 MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about what I said. I just want to help. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Mark just stands there for a moment, the only sounds comi from the players on the, field. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you two were going to watch some game. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I guess it's not really a game. It's more like a practice. Mark looks at his wife and Mother with concern. Ray doesn't understand this reaction. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, there's only eight of them, so they can't play a real game... MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight of what? Ray points to the noisy players on the field. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them. Now, Mother and Dee look as if they're about to go into mourning. Mark kneels next to Karin. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin honey... what are you watching? KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baseball men. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see any baseball men right now? KARIN (SLIGHTLY ANNOYED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do. Mark stands up and shoots Ray an accusing look. Annie's Mother starts to walk away. CONTINUED     34 61 CONTINUED (2) 61 MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's very polite to try to make other people feel stupid. Annie questions Mark and Dee as they pass her on the way to catch up with Mother. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't see it? DEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not funny, Annie. Her family leaves in a huff. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't see it. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. He and Annie sit beside Karin and watch the players. Each slowly starts to smile. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FIELD
dialogues.text: The practice is over, the players are perspired and exhilarated. Ray is over at first base talking with Swede Risberg, the shortstop. SWEDE RISBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, look at this. Sixty-five years since I worn this uniform, still fits me like a glove. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must keep in pretty good shape. SWEDE RISBERG (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I died in '75. So I ain't had a cigarette in, what, thirteen years. You don't smoke, do you? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. SHOELESS JOE (APPROACHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt good out there today, huh, guys? CONTINUED     35 62 CONTINUED 62 BUCK WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A! PLAYERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weaver! Buck realizes that once again he has cursed in front of Karin. WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit. I mean, sorry. I'm sorry. Annie calls from the house. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray! Dinner!

dialogues.speaker: SOME OF THE PLAYERS
dialogues.text: (FALSETTO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ra--ay! Dinner! They all laugh. Ray clearly loves being part of this locker room-style comradery. Karin runs to the house. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, fellas. Let's hit the showers. (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, Ray. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. See you guys. The players call their "good-byes" to Ray and head for th door in the outfield fence. Ray watches them fade out as they go through the door. Then he takes a moment to look around him. The baseball diamond set in the cornfield is quite beautiful. Ray takes a satisfied breath, and walks back toward his house. He is the very picture of contentment. Then he hears The Voice. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ease his pain.' Ray stops short. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No response. CONTINUED     36 62 CONTINUED (2) 62 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't understand. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ease his pain.' Ray stops short. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No response. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't understand. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Ease his pain.' RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose pain? What pain? No response. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me? But there is no response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray enters as Annie and Karin are putting dinner on the table. Ray plops- into his chair at the head of the table ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, wash up. We've got a PTA meeting after dinner. They're talking about banning books again. Really subversive books like, Wizard of Oz, Diary of Anne Frank --- She notices Ray is strangely silent. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you? PAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Voice is back. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, you don't have to build a football field now, do you? CONTINUED     37 63 CONTINUED" 63 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head no) He said...'Ease his pain.' ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ease whose pain? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked him. He wouldn't tell me. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoeless Joe's? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the other players? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very non-specific voice you've got out there, Ray, and he's really starting to piss me off. Ray nods as Annie serves the meal in silence. CUT TO 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parents stream in past the "PTA Meeting Tonite" sign. Ray and Annie stand by the doorway, talking with Miss Corser, Karin's teacher. (Ray is too distracted by his own thoughts to pay this much attention.) MISS CORSER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin has such a wonderful imagination. Lately, she's been making up these charming little stories about ghosts who play baseball in a cornfield... wonderful imagination. ANNIE (WITH A MYSTERIOUS SMILE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She gets that from Ray. Miss Corser smiles approvingly. Ray realizes both women are looking at him, now, and he emerges from his thoughts CONTINUED     38 64 CONTINUED 64 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? Annie leads Ray inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Annie -- along with a hundred or so other grownup -- are sitting in chairs too small for their grownup backsides. Ray is still lost in his own thoughts, doodlin "Ease his pain" over and over again, while an Irate Mothe has the floor, holding up a novel. IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .and I say smut and filth like this has no place in our schools! A large portion of the audience applauds. Annie whispers snarlingly to Ray: ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fascist. I'd like to ease her pain. Ray is still lost in thought. PRINCIPAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Perkins, the book you are waving about is hardly smut. It is considered by many critics as the classic novel about growing up in the 1960s. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Ray) I read it four times. Funniest book I ever read. IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pornography! PRINCIPAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Supreme Court said its not. And its author, Mr. Mann --- ANGRY FATHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- is sick! PRINCIPAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terence Mann is a Pulitzer prize-winner, and was widely regarded as the finest satirist of his time. IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think he's a pervert, and quite probably a Communist, too! CONTINUED     39 65 CONTINUED 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd murmurs its assent. ANNIE (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What planet are these people from? Ray looks as if he is starting to realize something. ANOTHER PARENT (READING FROM NOTES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The se-called novels of Terence Mann endorse promiscuity, godlessness, the mongrelization of races, and disrespect to high-ranking officers of the United States Army. And that's why right- thinking school boards all across the country have been banning this guy's shit since 1969. RAY (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terence Mann... IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why he stopped writing books? Because he masturbates! ANNIE (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take this anymore. RAY (VERY INTERESTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ,Terence Mann... Annie stands and smiles disarmingly. ANNIE (VERY REASONABLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, madam, but you're speaking of something about which you don't know squat. Terence Mann was a warm and gentle voice of.reason during a time of great madness. He coined the phrase 'Make Love, Not War.' When others were chanting 'Burn, baby, burn,' he was writing about love, and peace, and understanding. He helped define an era. And a generation. And he helped us laugh at ourselves. I cherished every one of his books, and I dearly wish he'd write more. And if you had experienced even a little bit of the Sixties, you might feel the same way, too. CONTINUED     40 65 CONTINUED (2) IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I experienced the sixties. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think you had two Fifties, and moved right on to the Seventies. IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Well your husband plowed under his corn and built a baseball field! The crowd "oohs" and "aahs." ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's an intelligent response. IRATE MOTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weirdo. Ray is so excited at his revelation that he really wants to leave immediately. He tugs Annie's sleeve. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie... But Annie mistakes her husband's intentions. She thinks he is cautioning her not to get embroiled in trouble. ANNIE (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, I'll be cool. (aloud, to the PARENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least he's not a book burner, you Nazi cow! Now the crowd erupts. IRATE PARENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both a bunch of weirdos! Annie pulls herself up to her full 5'4" and thrusts an angry finger at. the woman. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right Beulah, you wanna step outside?!? Huh? The other woman takes a half-step backward. No one has ever seen sweet Annie like this. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a better idea. Let's put it to a vote. Come on! Who's for Eva Braun (MORE) CONTINUED     41 65 CONTINUED (3) ANNIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: here? Who wants to burn books? Who wants to piss on the Constitution of the United Sates? Anybody? The majority who had sided with the book-banner wants to vote for censorship, but under these terms just can't rai their arms. Little Annie is on a roll, now. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Now: who's for The Bill of Rights? Come on...who thinks freedom's a pretty good thing? Let's see those hands. Some people start raising their hands. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who thinks we have to stand up to the kind of censorship they have in Russia? Reluctantly, just about everyone raises their hands. Anni is thrilled. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go. All right, America! I'm proud of you. I mean it. You're beautiful! RAY (RISING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, we gotta go. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) We gotta go. Ray pulls her from the room. Each is proud as hell, each for a different reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they burst out, bubbling over with their enthusiasm. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Ray, was that great, or what? it was like the Sixties again. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured it out. ANNIE (RELIVING IT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Step outside, you Nazi cow.' Ha-ha! CONTINUED     42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know whose pain I'm supposed to ease. ANNIE (STOPPING SHORT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know whose pain I'm supposed to ease. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, I just halted the spread of neo-facism in America, and you're talking about --- RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terence Mann. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's whose pain. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just know. I was right about building the field, wasn't I? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his pain? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how are you supposed to ease it? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. None of this questioning has dampened Ray's pride and excitement. Annie shakes her head. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray... RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie. CONTINUED     43 66 CONTINUED (2) 66 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries to put THIS GENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my favorite writer too, but...what's Terence Mann got to do with baseball? Ray's smile freezes. Then disappears. He hasn't a clue. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of Ray at the library: checking indices, readin old magazines, finding newspaper interviews on microfilm, s couring old anthologies, and taking copious notes. Some of the articles include: "Where is Terence Mann Now That We Really Need Him?". ."20 Rumors About America's Greatest Living Ex-Writer" ... and , "Terence Mann: Still Ignoring Us After All These Years ". The photographs show Mann to be a large black man with gentle eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Annie, it's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Annie run down the steps to the street for their car, Ray's words racing as fast as his feet. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the early Seventies, the guy decides people have become either too extremist or too apathetic to listen to him. So he stops writing books. He starts writing poetry. About whales and stuff. Then, he starts fooling around with a home computer, and gets hooked. Know what he does now? Annie shakes her head no. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He writes software for interactive children's videos. They teach kids how to resolve conflicts peacefully. What an amazing guy.. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. So what's it got to do with baseball? CONTINUED     44 68 CONTINUED 68 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the April 1962 issue of Jet Magazine, there's a story of his called 'This Is Not A Pipe.' Annie laughs at that. Ray is so excited, he laughs too. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not his best work, but the hero of the story, a character that Mann created twenty-six years ago, is named John Kinsella. My father. She stops short. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Wow. He gives her a "See? What'd I tell you?" look. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say... Big wow, but..what's it got to do with baseball? They are standing by their car. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie drives as Ray excitedly consults his notes. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. The last interview-he ever gave was in 1973. Guess what it's about. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. Some kind of team sport? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, he was a baseball fanatic! Listen to this: He finds a page and reads from it: RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'As a child, my earliest recurring dream was to play at Ebbets Field with Jackie Robinson and the Brooklyn Dodgers. Of course, it never happened, and the Dodgers left Brooklyn, and they torn down Ebbets Field. But even now, I still dream that dream.' CONTINUED     45 69 CONTINUED 69 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have arrived home and are walking into the house. He is still spouting things to her his research has uncovere RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man wrote the best books of his generation, he was a pioneer in the civil rights and anti-war movements, he made the cover of Newsweek, he knew everybody, he did everyting...he helped shape his time. He hung out with the Beatles! But in the end, it wasn't enough. What he missed ...was'baseball. Annie takes a look at Ray's handful of Xeroxes. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. ANNIE (SPOOKILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a small boy, he had a bat named 'Rosebud.' Ray disapprovingly grabs the Xeroxes back.from her. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. RAY (CONTINUES READING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't been to a live baseball game since 1958. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So to ease his pain, you have to take him to a ball game? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they enter and put away their things. CONTINUED     46 71 CONTINUED 71 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, this is nuttier than building the field. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not. It's pretty weird, I grant you, but building the field was weirder. Five, ten percent weirder. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, pal, but I have to nip this one in the bud. We are having moderate to heavy financial difficulties here. You cannot take off for Boston while you're going broke in Iowa. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, this is really new territory for both of us, I know, but we're dealing with primal forces of nature, here. When primal forces of nature tell you to do something, the prudent thing is not to quibble over details and --- ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to get PISSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why do you have to go? Why can't the voice send someone else? What's wrong with Shirley MacLaine, she too busy? What does this have to do with you??? Ray hears her anger and sits her down. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I need to find out. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, we're behind on the mortgage. That field ate up our savings. We could lose the farm. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't even stay in motels. I'll sleep in the car, and I'll beg for food. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is too much.- I understand your need to prove to the world you're not turning into your father, but you've done it! You believed in the magic, and it came true. Isn't that enough? CONTINUED     47 71 CONTINUED (2) 71 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, it's more than that. I know this- is nuts, but there's another reason I'm supposed to do it. I feel it. I feel it as strongly as I've ever felt anything in my life. There's a reason. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. Just tell me what it is. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think something's going to happen at the game. I don't know what, but...there's something at Fenway Park in Boston, and I have to be there with Terence Mann to find it. Something he just said changes Annie's mood. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fenway Park... Is that the one with the big green wall in left field? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamt last night you were at Fenway. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, was I sitting on the first base side? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the fifth row? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, OPEN-MOUTHED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were keeping score and eating RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a hot dog. I had the same dream. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you pack. CUT TO     48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is throwing clothes into a suitcase as fast as he can Annie reads from a road map she has marked for him. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .you take that to 93, and then it gets all squiggly, and after that you're on your own. How are you going to find him, anyway? He won't exactly be in the phone book, you know. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The article says he has a storefront on Harvard Street next to some place that sells Kosher food. Shouldn't be too hard to find. I don't need a tie, do

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, dear. Not for a kidnapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray has packed the car and is getting ready to leave. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be okay, right? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try to sell the combine. We sure don't need it anymore. Karin runs up, grabs Ray behind each ear and hugs and kisses him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long Tiger. He get into the car and looks up at Annie. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you every night. If the team shows up while I'm gone, just tell them... (shakes his head) On second thought, stay away from them. Those guys haven't been near a woman since 1922. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, they're not going to make a pass at me. They're'ghosts. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're jocks. Keep away from them. CONTINUED     49 7 3 CONTINUED 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs, kisses him, and watches him drive off. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROAD 74
dialogues.text: Ray's brave little Datsun chugs along the interstate between eighteen-wheelers, busses, gasoline tankers, auto-transport trucks, and other monsters. 75 TRAVELING MONTAGE 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving...gas stations...boring roadside restaurants... getting lost...looking at the map...signs that announce t "Entering" and "Leaving" of various states...days turning to nights and back again... .Finally, the green hills of Massachusetts. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: BOSTON
dialogues.text: He emerges from a tunnel and enters traffic, the likes of which he has not seen in a very long time. On one side of the expressway there are sweaty factories, and on the other, old wood-frame apartment buildings with advertisin for long-forgotten products painted on the sides. Lunatic drivers abound. We are not in Iowa anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rehearses as he drives. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Ray Kinsella. I'm really a big fan of... (DIFFERENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you, Mr. Mann, I have to take you to a baseball game. (SHAKES HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, put your hands up and get in the trunk! (FACETIOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: HARVARD STREET
dialogues.text: Ray drives slowly, looking for a store that sells Kosher food. But in this old newish neighborhood, there are dozens: butcher shops, delis, bakeries, groceries.     50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is asking the spritely Jewish Butcher for directions. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lives right around here. Do you know him? I'm a friend of his. The Butcher just stares back, with suspicion. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sort of a tall, black man. BUTCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you was much of a friend, he'd of give you the directions himself. Ray nods. He knows this is useless. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good point. Thank you. Ray exits. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET 80
dialogues.text: Ray has stopped an Ancient Jewish Woman on the street. Sh looks from Ray's Iowa license plate to Ray's face. ANCIENT WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where he lives. But by her raised eyebrows and the tone of her voice, it is clear that if she did know -- which she probably does -- she certainly wouldn't tell him. CUT TO 81 GAS STATION 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray has pulled his car to the edge of the gas station -- he is not buying gas -- and slips a five dollar bill to t ruddy-faced, teenaged Irish Pump Jockey. PUMP JOCKEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two blocks down. Right hand side. First store that don't have a chicken in the window, is his. CUT TO     51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In between a deli and a Kosher butcher shop, Ray finds a storefront with blacked-out windows. He enters an open hallway in which he sees the door to the storefront, as well as stairs to the apartments above it. There are half-a-dozen mail boxes on the wall. Ray checks the names. He smiles. 83 INSERT- MAILBOXES 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All but one have immigrant names. The first one reads: #1: TIE-DYED SOFTWARE. 84 RAY 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns to the storefront door. Instead of a buzzer there is a long wire with a weight on its end hanging fro a hole at the top of the door. Next to the wire is a handwritten note taped to the door, which reads: "You better have a goddamn good reason for ringing this bell." Ray laughs. This guy is great. He pulls on the wire. On the other side of the door, a bell rings. Ray has to struggle to control his nervousness. He takes a breath. He hears footsteps inside, approaching the door He cannot help but smile with delight at the thought of meeting one of his cultural heroes. The door opens. Terence Mann is menacingly huge. He glares at Ray and roars: MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you???- Ray is momentarily taken aback, but he figures maybe the guy is joking, so he just smiles and plunges ahead. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, my name is Ray Kinsella, and it's a great pleasure 'Co finally --- The door slams in his face. It takes Ray a few seconds to realize the interview is over. He rings the bell again. The door opens. MannВ°s large frame fills it. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a learning disability here? CONTINUED     52 84 CONTINUED 84 RAY (TALKS FAST)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mann, I've come 1500 miles to see you at the risk of losing my home and alienating my wife. If I could just have a minute. Please. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I can't tell you the secret of life, and I don't have any answers for you. I don't give interviews, I am no longer a public figure, I just want to be left alone. So fuck off. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one minute. I'm begging you. Mann looks him over. Then he sighs. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute. Mann turns and enters the storefront. Ray follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is hardly fashionable, but it's roomy and comfortable. There are tables stacked high with mailing envelopes and a postage scale. A few workbenches have software and spread sheets strewn across them. In the back are a coupl of personal computers. On a side wall there are book jackets and newspaper photo in cheap frames: pictures of Mann with Martin Luther King...with Bob Dylan...with Timothy Leary...rann being arrested at some demonstration.. .Mann at Woodstock... Mann's gruff voice pulls Ray's attention away from these relics. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your minute ain't getting bigger. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I understand your desire for privacy, and i wouldn't dream of intruding if this weren't extremely important. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. I don't do causes anymore. CONTINUED     53 85 -CONTINUED 85 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a cause. I don't need money, or an endorsement. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refreshing. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You once wrote: 'There comes a time when all the cosmic tumblers have clicked into place, and the universe opens itself up for a few seconds, to show you what is possible.' MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the Sixties! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually --- MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! Out! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait a second --- Mann picks up an old-fashioned bug sprayer -- the kind wi a long arm that pumps in and out -- and starts spraying i at Ray as if he were an unwanted insect. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the Sixties! Back! He is backing Ray out the door. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd just --- MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
