dialogues.text: There's no place for you here in the future! Get back while you still can! He gets Ray just past the door and slams it shut. Ray slams it open. He's pissed. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've changed, you know that? CONTINUED     54 85 CONTINUED (2) 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mann stops fuming and considers that. He sighs, sadly. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose I have. How's this? (smiles and makes the peace sign) 'Peace, love, dope.' (ROARS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get the fuck out of here!!! And he slams the door shut again. Ray is flabbergasted. He is thinking furiously. Then he notices that in slammin the door, the latch has not locked in place. He thinks, makes up his mind, and quietly opens the door. Mann has returned to work, his back to the door. Ray enters the loft, his left hand in his jacket pocket. When he is halfway across the loft, he clears his throat. Mann spins around. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you've pissed me off. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, hold it right there. He juts his pocketed hand forward, as if he had a gun in his jacket. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping I wouldn't have to do it this way... MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gun. What'd you think it is? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your finger. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not. It's a gun. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Let me see it. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here, I'm not going to show you my gun. Mann sighs, and stands. CONTINUED     55 85 CONTINUED (3) 85 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look. I'm not going to hurt you, I just need you to go with me for a little while, then -- what are you doing? Mann has found a crowbar among his tools, and is advancin toward Ray. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to beat you with a crowbar till you go away. Understandably, this makes Ray nervous. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Wait! You can't do that. MANN (STILL ADVANCING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, are there rules? There's no rules. Mann is almost to him, now, the crowbar raised above his head. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pacifist! Mann stops. He thinks. He lowers the crowbar. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Ray breathes a sigh of relief. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, are you kidnapping me? What's the deal here? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was hoping I could-just convince you to come with me. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are kidnapping me. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to take you to a baseball game. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what? CONTINUED     56 - 85 CONTINUED (4) 85 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight's game. Red.Sox, Twins. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something will happen there. I don't know what, but we'll find out when it does. Mann now has no idea what to make of all this, so he just looks Ray over for a few seconds. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Ray Kinsella. You used my father's name for a character in one of your stories. John Kinsella. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're seeing a team of psychiatrists, aren't you? RAY (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you for thinking that, but no, I'm not. I swear to God I'm the least crazy person I've ever known. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you kidnapping me to a baseball game? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read an interview you gave a long time ago about how you always dreamed of playing at Ebbets Field, and how sad you felt when they tore it down. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head no) I never said that. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even remember thinking it. Now Ray is ndt sure what to do. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole. thing is so weird. CONTINUED     57 85 CONTINUED (5) 85 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why go through with it? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story...and I'll tell you on the way. Please. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to get rid of you, am I? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you just come to this game with me, I'll never bother you again. Not even a Christmas card. Mann picks up a hat, .plops it on his head and heads out the door. CUT TO 86 CITY STREETS 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mann sits tensely beside Ray, who drives with his right hand, while his left hand remains in his pocket, substituting for a gun. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do this often? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's my first time. So be gentle. Ray laughs nervously, and is embarrassed to see Mann not sharing the humor. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to have a sense of humor. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things used to be funny. Ray pulls up at an intersection. He has to choose between left and right. Behind him, cars are honking. Ray doesn't have a clue which way to go. He sighs. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This is really humiliating. Which way is-Eenway? Mann shakes his head, then tilts it to the left. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. CONTINUED     58 86 CONTINUED 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray makes the turn, and heads off down the street. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really inept at this, aren't you? Ray grins sheepishly and nods. Mann laughs. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you're like a total bumbler. Ray chuckles his reluctant acceptance of the truth. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bozo the Kidnapper. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no longer so AMUSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... After a few moments, Ray decidesto break the ice. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question? Something I've always wanted to know. Mann nods. He's been asked this question a million times. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I never slept with her. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never slept with who? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever you were going to ask me about. If I'd been with one-tenth the famous women they said I was with, I'd be in formaldehyde by now. RAY (INTERESTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You slept with a lot of famous women? MANN (SOURLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your question? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get a name like Terence? Mann cannot believe that's the question. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rastus was taken. CONTINUED     59 86 CONTINUED (2) 86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray knows now to shut up. He returns his attention to his driving, glances up to his rearview mirror, and sees something that causes his eyes to widen in horror. 87 REAR-VIEW MIRROR 87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Boston police car on his tail, red lights flashing.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mann looks behind him, sees the police car, and turns bac to Ray. Ray wears a look of resignation as he pulls the car over to the side of the road, and shuts off the ignition. Mann just looks at him, and starts to chuckle. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice going, Boze. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I don't really have a gun. So don't say anything to this guy, okay? I swear to God there's a reason we're supposed to be at this game. Mann gives him a "Give me a break" look. Ray sees the Policeman is getting out of his cruiser and walking towards them. Ray is desperate. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I get arrested, the press'll be all over you, you'll have to appear in open court, you'll be the lead story on Entertainment Tonight, and your picture'll be on the front page of every tabloid in America. The Policeman knocks on Ray's window. He is young, fresh-scrubbed and earnest. Ray holds up one hand to him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second. (-CO MANN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Terence-Mann Kidnapped... Also seen in UFO with Elvis.' Mann's eyes narrow. The cop knocks again, more insistently. Ray rolls down-the window." CONTINUED'     60 88 CONTINUED 88 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: License and registration. Nervously, Ray complies. Mann turns his face toward the passenger side window. Ray's mouth dries up. He has no idea what Mann will do. The Policeman scrutinizes the license, turns it over to look for convictions, and checks Ray's face against the felonlike photo. Then he looks at Mann. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's your name,-sir? Mann keeps his face averted. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it that you and Raymond are going, Terry? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fenway Park! We're going to the ball game. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to cop) Actually, Officer, I'm being kidnapped. Discreetly, under his breath, Ray sings the "Entertainmen Tonight" theme song. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Entertainment Tonight, doo-doo-doo-doo-doo-doo... Mann winces. The officer looks at him questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: MANN,
dialogues.text: What I mean by that is, I don't care much for baseball, but Raymond insisted. POLICEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hate baseball. (hands Ray back HIS ID)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your right taillight is out, Raymond. I want you to get it fixed at the first opportunity. CONTINUED     61 88 CONTINUED (2) 88 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I will. Thank you. The Policeman walks away, and Ray heaves a sigh of relief RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Terry?' MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Raymond?' RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. My...hostages call me Ray. Can I call you Terry? Sourly, Mann nods. Ray smiles and drives off. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And thank you. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it just because I don't want the publicity. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what else? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envy you your craziness, Ray. It's been years since I did something completely crazy. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you want to hear something really crazy? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have a choice? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. I live on a farm in Iowa. One day, out in the cornfield, I heard a voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It glides through city traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray slides the Datsun into a parking place, and he and Ma walk the short sleazy block to Fenway, and old-fashioned center-city ballpark. CONTINUED     62 90 CONTINUED 90 MANN (SHAKING HIS HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can't you accept the probability that it's all just a hallucination? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Karin see it, too. They have reached the ticket window. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, field level, first base side. The elderly Ticket Seller pulls out two tickets. TICKET SELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Section seventeen. Twelve dollars. Ray takes out his wallet and turns to Mann.. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on me. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn right it is. Ray pays the man and receives the tickets. TICKET SELLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game don't start for a while, but you can go in, watch batting practice. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. They enter the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk through the indoor portion of the grandstand toward their section. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you do with yourself these days? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live. I work. I've learned to cook. I take walks. I watch sunsets. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you miss being... involved? CONTINUED     63 91 CONTINUED 91 MANN (SNORTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the East Coast distributor of 'involved.'. I ate it, drank it, and breathed it. Then they killed Martin. They killed Bobby. And then they elected Tricky Dick. Twice. And now, people like you think I must be miserable that I'm not involved anymore. Well, I've got news for you: I spent all my misery years ago. I have no more pain for any of you. I gave at the office. They approach the refreshment stand. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: . MANN
dialogues.text: I want them to stop looking to me for answers. Begging me to speak again, write again, be a leader. I want them to start thinking for themselves. And I want my privacy! Ray looks slightly embarrassed. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I meant what do you want from... Ray points to the hot dog vendor, as they have reached th front of the line. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (LAUGHS AT HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog and a beer. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the vendor) Two. (TO MANN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I agree, you should be entitled to as much privacy as you wane. But why stop writing? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't published a word in seventeen years and I still have to endure assholes like you all the time. What do you think it'd be like if I suddenly came out with a new book? CONTINUED     64 91 CONTINUED (2) 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods. Mann is making sense. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd bleed me dry. 92 SECTION SEVENTEEN 92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Mann emerge into the sunlight and walk down the aisle toward the field. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, this place is so beautiful. The grass is so green you can almost smell it. Looking around the old ballpark, they see only about twenty or thirty die-hard fans in the stands for batting practice; a half-dozen players are grouped around the batting cage as one player hits to several others in the field. A few sportswriters and other civilians stand near the dugouts. Ray and Mann stop at the first row, right behind the Red Sox on-deck circle, lean on the railing and talk. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be 1912 out there, for all this place has changed. Babe Ruth stood on that very mound as a pitcher long before anyone knew he could hit home runs. Same mound. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we here, Ray? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something.. about the game. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is in progress. Ray and Mann are in their fifth row seats. They do not speak. At one point, Ray becomes suddenly and strangely aware th something is about to happen. He looks at Mann who is jus watching the game. Then he looks at the scoreboard. 94 THE SCOREBOARD 94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fenway Park has a sophisticated scoreboard that flashes pictures of the batter and pitcher, and can show instant replays of some of the action. CONTINUED     65 94 CONTINUED 94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, the display is replaced by an oddly glowing message. The sounds of the stadium, the game, and the crowd fade out. There is only the message:

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIBALD "MOONLIGHT" GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Chisholm, Minn. New York Giants LIFETIME STATISTICS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 Game, 0 At Bats The message does not just glow, it pulsates. It looks almost otherworldly, phosphorescent; clearly unlike anything ever seen before on a ballpark scoreboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks around him. The sounds of the game return, and from the unconcerned faces of the people near him, he realizes that no one else can see the message. He opens his program and starts writing it down. Mann notices this but cannot see what Ray is writing. Then Ray hears The Voice. THE VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Go the distance.' RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? Ray sighs. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. ;THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever you wanttogo,wecan go. CONTINUED     66 95 CONTINUED 95 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to go, we can go. Mann looks at Ray curiously, trying to read this new attitude. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's go. Mann rises and heads up the aisle. Ray looks down at the program -- at the handwritten legend of Moonlight Graham, who played one game fifty-seven years ago, but did not ge to bat -- and follows Mann out of the ballpark. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: THE RIDE BACK TO BOSTON 96
dialogues.text: It is nighttime, and Mann drives. Ray slumps, dozing, troubled. Mann looks curiously at Ray, but says nothing. They ride in silence. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is blue with moonlight as they park in front o the storefront. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you goingfrom here? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you're not telling me? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head no) I've taken up too much of your time. Mann gets out of the car. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had your passion, Ray. However misdirected it may be, it's still a passion. I used to feel that way about things, but... CONTINUED     67 97 CONTINUED 97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray slides into the driver's seat. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got another message, didn't you? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll think I'm crazy. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already think you're crazy. What did it say? After a little thought, Ray smiles sadly. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It said 'The man's done enough. Leave him alone.' Ray puts the car in gear, makes a wide turn, and starts t head back up the street. But he stops short when Mann's form looks out of the darkness into the glare of the headlights.. Ray does not know why Mann is blocking his path. Or why he appears tense, almost frightened. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Moonlight' Graham. Ray's jaw drops. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw it. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw what? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York Giants, 1922. He played one game, never got to bat. Mann looks spectrial in the high-contrast glare on the headlights. MANN. What did I see, Ray? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chisholm, Minnesota. We were the only ones who saw it. Did you hear the voice, too? Mann glances at Ray, then looks away. CONTINUED     68 97 CONTINUED (2) 97 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right to admit it. That's what told me to find you. No response. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear it too? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Go the distance.' RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it means? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means...we're going to Minnesota to find Moonlight Graham. RAY (THRILLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do when we find him? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll know that when we find him. Ray opens the passenger door of the Datsun and Mann jumps in. Ray releases the brake and peels out, burning rubber. The two men look happy as kids with bats over shoulders, gloves dangling, on their way to a sandlot. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once on 1-90, they begin the long haul across the Great Lakes states. Ray drives, Mann dozes in the reclined passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Annie, I'm really sorry, but I'm going to be a few days longer. CONTINUED     69 98 CONTINUED 98

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (PHONE; FILTERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ray...Is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everything's great, and'I'll tell you all about it when I get back, but I'm going to Minnesota now.

dialogues.speaker: MORE ON THE ROAD 99
dialogues.text: Now Mann drives, and Ray tries to sleep, his stockinged feet propped up on the dash, occasionally sliding with a thud against the steering column.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (PHONE; FILTERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this. What's in Minnesota?

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V. 0.)
dialogues.text: An old ballplayer. I'll explain when I get home. How are things with you? 100 GAS STATION 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is using the pay phone on the wall of the office, whi the car is being gassed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (PHONE; FILTERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, fine. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guess what? Terence Mann is with me. We're going to Minnesota together.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (PHONE; FILTERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Oh, Ray, that's unbelievable! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I gotta go. Hug Karin for me. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (PHONE; FILTERED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too. You guys behave yourselves. Hurry home. CONTINUED     70 100 CONTINUED 100

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray smiles and hangs up. CUT TO 101 ANNIE'S KITCHEN 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, and loses her smile as she turns back to th kitchen table, where her brother Mark sits with two men i business suits. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell him? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the same reason I've never pissed on your birthday cake. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, you don't have a choice in the matter. Annie looks vertroubldye. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are north of Duluth,andthelandscape hasgrown harsher, the trees shorterandmore gnarled, thegrass tougher and wirier. After Virginia, Minnesota, all the land is scarred. Above the town the mines sit like sand-colored bunkers in the cliffs,- stern and silent. Near Chisholm, the land is getting ever weirder. It looks like a pasture rooted and rerooted by giant hogs. It has been split and gutted; greenery has grown back, but at weird and unnatural angles. But as they swing into town; the highway divides and they cross a beautiful and tranquil lake, so smooth and shiny it might be a scene painted on a glass plate. A sign read WELCOME TO CHISHOLM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Mann have parked on the main street next to a corner phone booth. Ray is flipping through the thin phon book attached to the booth by a chain. CONTINUED     71 103 CONTINUED 103 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a dozen Grahams...no Archibald, no Moonlight. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local newspaper is located in a small storefront that was probably once a confectioners or a dry-goods store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Mann are talking with the paper's publisher, Veda Ponikvar, a handsome woman in her sixties, with a sweet, innocent smile, and eyeglasses hanging from a fine chain around her neck. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to find an ex-baseball player named Archibald Graham. VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean 'Doc' Graham. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think his nickname was 'Moonlight.' VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's Doctor Graham. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Graham. This is interesting news to Ray and Mann. VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His baseball career never amounted to much, so he went back to school. His father was a doctor. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where we can find him? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing bad. We're not from the IRS, or anything --- CONTINUED     72 105 CONTINUED 105 VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Graham is dead. He died in 1972. Ray and Mann look at each other, unsure of what this mean to their quest. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER BACK ROOM 106
dialogues.text: Ray and Mann sit at a table in the newspaper's back room, the "morgue" file on Doc Graham -- a collection of clippings, pictures, and the obituary -- strewn before them. Right now, their attention is on Veda, who has put her glasses on, and is reading from an editorial. VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .'And there were times when children could not afford eyeglasses or milk, or clothing. Yet no child was ever denied these essentials, because in the background, there was always Doctor Graham. Without any fanfare or publicity, the glasses or the milk or the ticket to the ball game found their way into the child's pocket.' MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wrote that. VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day he died. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good writer. The compliment is just right, and she smiles warmly. VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She exits. Mann spreads out the clippings and shakes his head. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's missing. Ray is looking at a photo of Doc Graham as a man in his late sixties. CONTINUED     MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the towns in North America has a Doc Graham. What makes this one so special we have to come halfway across the country to find him fifteen years after he died? There's got to be more. Veda enters with a piece of paper from a yellow legal pad VEDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to talk to some of these people. They knew Doc pretty well. Mann takes the list and looks it over. CUT TO 107 INTERVIEW 07

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two old Codgers on a park bench. FIRST CODGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that man had an arm on him. One day over at the ballpark, he said 'Lemme see that ball', and one of the boys threw him the ball, and he walked over behind home plate, reared back, and fired that ball over the left field fence. SECOND CODGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was at least fifty years old when he did it. FIRST CODGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was still rising when it disappeared. 108 INTERVIEW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman, an older Nurse. NURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i went with him to make a housecall at one of the camps. .mining camps. The husband was sick, and they had no stove, so they had no heat. (MORE) CONTINUED     74 108 CONTINUED NURSE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we got back to Chisholm, Doc went to the hardware store and bought a stove for them and paid to have it delivered. And I know that wasn't the only time he did something like that.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY KITCHEN RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Several tables have been pushed together, and Mann sits surrounded by townspeople, mostly men past retirement age BALDING MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't smoke or drink, .but he used to chew up paper and spit it out wherever he went. If you were around Doc very long, you learned to duck. MOUSTACHED MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd even chew up his prescription slips, so sometimes we'd have to dig into our pockets for a piece of paper so Doc could write us prescriptions. WHITE-HAIRED MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always wore a black overcoat, even in the summer, and it was always flapping open, even in the winter and it was fifty below. And he had white hair, like me, and he always carried an umbrella. SMOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cept he was always, I mean always, losing them. Stores 'round town would just lean his umbrella somewhere near the door, and if anybody asked, they'd just say 'Oh, that's Doc's umbrella'. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the umbrella for? WHITE-HAIRED MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I think it got to be a habit, something to hang onto. But if you'd ask him, he'd say it was to beat away all his lady admirers. This, as much as the other remembrances, brings warm chuckles to the old men. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about his wife. CONTINUED     75 109 CONTINUED BALDING MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alicia. She moved to South Carolina after he passed. She passed a few years later. She always wore blue. I bet you didn't know that. MANN (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman Manager of the motel is having a'cup of coffee with Ray. MOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, everybody's talking about you two. Our neighbors came over last night and we just told Doc'Graham stories until after midnight. I even wrote some of them down. She takes out a piece of paper. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you. MOTEL MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's funny. It's like all these memories we have of Doc had gone to sleep and sunk way down inside us. But once you started asking about him, and started us talking about him, why they swum back up to the surface again. Ray smiles. CUT TO 111 MOTEL ROOM 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Mann are sitting in their beds, comparing their notes. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No screwing, no drinking, no opium, no illegitimate children. No-midnight abortions, no shady finances. Ray puts down his notes and picks up the Chicago Tribune. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound disappointed. CONTINUED     76 111 CONTINUED 111 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoeless Joe had a problem. That's why he needed you. This guy doesn't need us. Suddenly, Ray straightens with a start. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, My God. Ray hurries over to Mann, offering the opened newspaper, and points out an article to Mann. It is headlined: TERENCE MANN MISSING. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. (READS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'His son, who lives in New York City, notified police after receiving no answer to repeated telephone calls...' Shit. I'd better call him. He pulls the phone onto the bed and dials MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do I tell him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to...? He motions outside with his head. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Ray exits. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks by the old movie theatre, which sits at the edg of a residential street. The Godfather is playing. He nods at an elderly man who passes him on the street. He passes a darkened house and notices there is a sign of so kind in its unlit front window. He takes another two or three steps before he has, to stop to take a better look the sign.     77 113 THE SIGN 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a second to make out the image in the dark, but it is a head shot of Richard Nixon. Above, it says "Four More Years". Below, it reads "Re-Elect The President". 114 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1.14 is puzzled. He turns and looks at the theatre marquee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the letters that spell out "The Godfather", are smaller letters that read "Nominated for 10 Academy Awards". 116 RAY 116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frowns. He says the word to himself. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nominated? Ray now looks at the car parked nearest to him. 117 THE CAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an old Mustang. The annual tag on the license plate reads: 1972. 118 ?? RAY 118 LOOKS-AROUND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the cars on the street are pre-1972. And still walkin down the block away from him, is the elderly man Ray pass moments earlier. The man is about sixty-five years old, stooped a little, but the body is still lithe, an athlete's body. He is wearing a dark overcoat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .and he carries an umbrella.     78 121 RAY 121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little hairs on the back of Ray's neck stand up. His mouth is dry, and for a moment, he cannot speak. Then, he calls to the man. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Graham? Slowly, the man stops and turns back to face Ray. Ray starts to trot to him. ELDERLY MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Ray Kinsella. I'm from Iowa. Are you Moonlight Graham? The old man narrows his bright eyes to see Ray more clearly. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's called me 'Moonlight' Graham for fifty years. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've come... (SMILES TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . a very long way to see you. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. I couldn't sleep tonight. Usually, I sleep like a baby. So I told Alicia I was going to take a walk. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if i join you? I'd like to talk to you. Doc nods and they start to walk. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to the high school. We can sit in my office. What do. you want to talk about? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first of all, how'd you get to be called 'Moonlight'? DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause of a night like this, long ago. I'd just gotten to the minors, and I went out to the ballpark. (MORE) CONTINUED     79 121 CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOC GRAHAM (Cont'd} There's nothing as peaceful as a ballpark at night. Like a church. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know what you mean. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I fell asleep. Next morning, they found me in the on-deck circle, all curled up like a baby. Someone called me 'Moonlight,' and it stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc fumbles out a key, and lets them in. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you got to the majors, you played only one inning of one game. What happened in that inning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the hallway of the old school, the smell of varnish and chalk almost palpable. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the last day of the season. Bottom of the eighth, and we were way ahead. I'd been up with the club for most of a month, but hadn't seen any action. Just then old John McGraw points a bony finger at me and says 'Right field.' Well sir, I jumped up like I was sitting on a spring, grabbed my glove, and ran out onto the field. They reach a varnished door with an opaque glass inset, a enter. Doc Graham's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc seats himself behind a cluttered desk, and motions Ra to the black-leather sofa a few feet away. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get to make a play? Doc takes a sheet of paper off his desk, expertly rips an inch or so off the corner with his teeth, and begins chewing. CONTINUED     80 124 CONTINUED 124 DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. They never hit the ball out of the infield. Ray chuckles, but then flinches as Doc shoots his little spitball towards him. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads up. It hits the back of the sofa a few feet from Ray, and han there, like a white fly. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was warned about you. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, one inning later the game was over, and so was I. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was that like? DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like coming this close to your dreams, and then watching them brush past you like a stranger in a crowd. Ray nods, and a look of understanding begins to appear on his face. He looks out the window, focused on faraway. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except, at the time, you don't think much of it. Hardly anybody recognizes the most significant moment of their life when they're happening. Back then I just figured there'd be plenty more days. I didn't know that would be the only one. Doc Graham notices that Ray is looking very serious. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, let me ask you a question, Ray Kinsella. What makes that half-inning so interesting that you come all the way from Iowa to ask me about it sixty-five years later? Ray chooses his words carefully. CONTINUED     81 124 CONTINUED (2) 124 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't really know till just now. But I think it's to ask you if you could do anything you wanted to...if you could have a wish... DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh... Doc nods. his understanding. He smiles wryly, takes a new piece of paper, and bites off a little section. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And are you the kind of man who could grant me that wish? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm just asking... Doc leans his left elbow on the desk and rubs his forehea thoughtfully with a palm, as if it were an eraser that could erase the years and take him back to 1929 and the Polo Grounds in New York. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never got to bat in the major leagues. I'd have liked the chance -- just once -- to stare down a big league pitcher. Stare him down and then just as he goes into the windup -- wink! Make him wonder if I know something he doesn't. That's what I wish for. The chance to squint my eyes when the sky is so blue it hurts to look at it, and to feel the 'tingle that runs up your arms when you connect dead-on. The chance to run the bases, stretch a double to a triple, and flop race-first into third, wrapping my arm around the bag. That's my wish, Ray Kinsella... that's my wish. Ray begins to smile. Graham is staring intently at him. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there enough magic floating around in the night out there for you to make that wish come true? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you do if I said 'Yes'? DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I might actually believe you. CONTINUED     82 124 CONTINUED (3) RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a place where things like that happen. And if you want to go there, I can take you. Doc's eyes start to glisten, and he offers an embarrassed smile as he wipes away a tear. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it means leaving Chisholm... He shakes his head.no. Ray is surprised. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, but I think you're supposed to come with us. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my most special place in the world, Ray. Once a place touches you like this, the wind never blows so cold again. You feel for it like it was your child. I can't leave here. Ray cannot believe the man won't leave Chisholm for his dream. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your wish... DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll stay one. I was born here, lived here, and I'll die here. That's okay. I'll have no regrets. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sixty-five years ago -- for five minutes -- you came this close. (holds up two FINGERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would kill some men to get that close to their dream and never touch it. They'd consider it a tragedy. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son...if I'd only gotten to be a doctor for five minutes. .now that would have been a tragedy. Those words fill up the room, and Ray sinks back against the couch. CONTINUED     83 124 CONTINUED (4) 124 DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd better get home before Alicia starts to thinking I've got a girlfriend. And Doc Graham smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And he smiled. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later that same night, and Ray has been recounting his experience with Doc Graham to Mann, who appears quiet troubled. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I figured maybe we're not supposed to take him with us. So now I don't know why the hell we were supposed to come here. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was to find out if one inning can change the world. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did for these people. If he'd gotten a hit, he might've stayed there. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife called before. She wants you to call her tonight. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is asleep. The phone rings, and the speed with whic she picks it up suggests that her anxiety to get this pho call prevented her from sleeping very deeply. CONTINUED     84 126 CONTINUED 126 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. (PAUSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked the bank if we could miss a payment or two, and they told me they'd just sold the note on the farm to Mark and his partners. So they own the paper now, and he says if we don't sell to them, they'll foreclose. Ray, we don't have the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray holds the phone, pained. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, look. They can't foreclose for thirty days, or something like that. I've got to take Terry back to Boston first, so it'll be --- MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Ray looks over at Mann. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Iowa with you. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're coming home.- CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ROAD
dialogues.text: Ray drives with purpose and speed. Mann looks relaxed. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I couldn't quit now. I've got see this ballpark. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everybody can see it. You might not. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give it a try. As they turn onto the highway near the lake, a Teenager with a dufflebag appears on the side of the road, his arm raised in. a hitchhiker's stance. Ray pulls the car over to the side of the road. CONTINUED     85
128 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need all the karma I can get right now. The car stops, and the Teenager runs for it. He tosses hi dufflebag in the backseat and squeezes in after it. TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You're the first car by. I didn't expect to get a lift so soon. Ray starts the car back onto the highway. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far are you going? TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far are you going? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iowa. TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's okay with you, I'll ride along for a while. I play baseball. Ray and Mann exchange brief smiles. TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a place to play, and I heard that all through the Midwest, towns have teams, and in some places they'll find you a day job so you can play ball nights and weekends. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your lucky day, kid. We're going someplace kind of like that. TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ray Kinsella, this is Terry Mann. TEENAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Archie Graham. Mann and Ray just look at each other. And the little Datsun heads off down the highway. CUT TO     86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie sleeps in the backseat. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to ask him if he has a nickname. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. He didn't get it till he was in the minors. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can give it to him. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, the way he described towns, finding you a job so you can play on their team...they haven't done that for years. My Dad did that for a while. But that was in the Twenties. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your father? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never made it as ball player, so he tried to get his son to make it for him. By the time I was ten, playing baseball got to be like eating vegetables or taking out the garbage, so when I was fourteen, I started to refuse. Can you believe that? An American boy refusing to have a catch with his father. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why at fourteen? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when I read The Boat Rocker, by Terence Mann. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never played catch with him again. MANN (SERIOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, that's the kind of crap people are always trying to lay on me. It's not my fault you wouldn't play catch with your father! CONTINUED     87 129 CONTINUED 129 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Anyway, when I was seventeen, we had a big fight, I packed my things, said something awful, and left. After a while I wanted to come home, but I didn't know how. I made it back for the funeral. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the awful thing you said? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I could never respect a man whose hero was a criminal. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was his hero? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoeless Joe Jackson. Mann considers this all very carefully. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew he wasn't a criminal. Ray nods. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd you say it? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was seventeen. Mann nods with growing understanding. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is your penance. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I can't bring my father back.. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .so the least you can do is bring back his hero. Ray nods. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now we know what everybody's purpose here is...except mine. Ray looks at him. He hadn't thought of that. After a few moments Ray points to something in the distance.     88

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something down the road, in the midst of all this flat farmland, is glowing in the night. It is an illuminated baseball diamond in a cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: RAY AND ANNIE'S FARM
dialogues.text: Ray turns the Datsun into the long driveway and, with a rumble, crosses the metal cattle guard that keeps livesto from escaping to the roadway. He eases the car to a stop in front of the house, and as the three men unfold themselves from the car, Karin bolts from the back door of the house, a blur of white blouse a pink pedal pushers. She flings herself into Ray's arms, and hugs his neck in unrestrained joy. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! Then Annie appears too. They kiss while Mann and Archie wait to be introduced. Finally, Mann clears his throat. RAY ( (BEAMING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin, Annie... This is Terence Mann MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya Terry. Annie steps forward, wining some curls from her eyes with ahand that has recently been immersed in flour'. She smiles, wipes the hand on the thigh of her jeans, and shakes his hand. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this young fellow is Moon -- uh, Archie Graham. Karin and Annie shake his hand. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's come to practice with the team. CONTINUED     89 131 CONTINUED 131 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be able to do more than just practice. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. They walk towards the field. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's enjoy this place while we still have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Annie walk silently with their arms around each other as they lead Mann, Archie and Karin to the bleacher Mann's eyes widen as several of the players shout greetin to Ray. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ray, welcome back. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Joe. Good to see you. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Lord. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Shoeless Joe Jackson! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course it is. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen pictures. Those are the White Sox! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you still didn't believe me? MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I did, but... Oh my Lord. They have reached the foul line where Shoeless Joe waits for them. CONTINUED     90 132 CONTINUED 1321 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, I'd like you to meet Joe Jackson. Joe, this is Terry Mann. Mann and Jackson shake hands. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure to meet you. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure's mine. (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, I hope you don't mind, but we got tired of just having practices, so we brought another team out with us so we could have some real games. He points to the visitors' bench, and, indeed, there are a dozen or so more old-time baseball players in old-time baseball uniforms. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind. Where'd they come from? SHOELESS JOE (CHUCKLES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd we come from. Man, you wouldn't believe how many guys wanted to play here. We had to beat 'em off with a stick. ARCHIE (FROM THE BLEACHERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's Mel Ott. And Carl Hubbell. Those are the New York Giants! SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a couple of Cardinals and A's thrown in for good measure. Ty Cobb wanted to play, but none of us could stand the sonofabitch when we were alive, so we told him to stuff it. (TO ARCHIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, are you Graham? ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Ray and Mann are astonished that Shoeless Joe knows who Archie is. CONTINUED     91 132 CONTINUED (2) 132 SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you doing on the sidelines? You came here to play ball, didn't you? ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go warm up! ARCHIE (THRILLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir! Archie quickly scampers down the bleachers, onto the fiel shakes Joe's hand, and runs to the dugout. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than that. It's perfect. CUT TO 133 THE GAME 133

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White Sox are in the field, the Giants at bat. A Gian hitter bunts, and the runner on second takes third despit a close throw. Mann, Ray, Karin and Annie are in the stands, Mann keepin score. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he get a hit for that? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin? KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, no. The batter was trying to sacrifice. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how do you score it? KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fielder's choice? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. CONTINUED     92 133 CONTINUED 133

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mann is impressed. He lifts Karin up from her seat on the row below them, and places her next to him to help him. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better sit here. Karin beams. Ray taps Mann and points to the plate. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Archie Graham -- now wearing a Giant's uniform -- drops o of the two bats he has been swinging in the on-deck circl and advances on the plate, slashing the air with a brand-new bat the color of vanilla ice cream. He plants himself in the batter's b.ox, then cocks the bat, the top end of it trembling as if he were stirring something, and waits for the pitch.' The pitcher looks in for his signs. Archie stares back. As the pitcher goes into his windup, Archie winks at him. There is a moment of confusion and then anger on the pitcher's face, and when the ball speeds to the plate it is aimed right at Archie's head. He dives out of the way and hits the dirt hard. The Catcher chuckles through his mask. CATCHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing for you that wasn't his fastball. Archie digs in again at the plate, but backs up just a little. Now his look to the pitcher is one of determination. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's see your fastball. The pitcher smiles, winds up and throws. Very fast. And right at Archie's chin. Again, he has to dive out of the way. This time, however, he gets right up and immediately appeals to the Umpire. ARCHIE В°

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, ump, how about a warning? UMPIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Watch out-you don't get killed. Both benches laugh at that. Archie holds up his hands to call time, and steps out of the batter's box. The on-deck batter, Mel Ott, comes over. CONTINUED     93 133 CONTINUED (2) 133 OTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, kid, first two were high and tight, where do you think the next one's going to be? ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either-low and away, or in my ear. OTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't want to load the bases. Look for low and away. Archie nods and starts to walk back to the plate. OTT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But watch out for 'in your ear.' Archie takes his place in the batter's box again. He stil looks determined, but a little less cocky. The next pitch is a curve that looks as if it's heading right for him. But he holds his ground, and when the ball breaks down an away, he steps in, snaps the bat forward, and hits it. The ball sails in a high arc to right center. The center fielder backs up a couple of steps, lopes a few strides t his left, and makes the catch. Archie is out, but the runner on third tags up and scores As Archie curls across the diamond from the first baselin to the Giants' bench, he hears cheering. In the stands, Ray, Annie, Karin and Mann are giving him a standing ovation. In return, he touches the brim of his cap, a ballplayer's cool response to adulation. MANN (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В•Look at that. Mr. Cool. But when Archie gets to the bench, he can't contain himse anymore. He leaps up and lets out a cheer of pure joy. DISSOLVE TO

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: The game has ended, and players are rough-housing and joking as they slowly make their way to the door in the outfield fence. Ray and Mann are talking to some of the players over the fence. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you go when you walk through that door? What do you do? CONTINUED     94 134 CONTINUED CHICK GANDIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sleep. HAPPY FELSCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wait. SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dream. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave the field any other way, can you? SHOELESS JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if we want to come back. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to go with you sometime. The silence that follows is long and ominous. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see what's out there. There is still no response. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that as a no for now. He spots Archie jogging off the field. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, slugger, congratulations! Archie jogs over. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I can't stop shaking I'm so happy. 'Course, I would've liked a base hit... KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you got a RBI! ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure did, didn't I? SHOELESS JOE (YELLS BACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rookie's luck! They all laugh at that. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well come on, this calls for a drink. CONTINUED     95 134 CONTINUED (2) 134

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie hesitates. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm... He motions with his head toward the other players disappearing through the outfield door. Ray nods understandingly. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good game, Archie. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, kid. Ray, Karin, Annie and Mann watch Archie jog towards the rest of the players. When he reaches the fence, he turns back to them. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kinsella? Ray turns toward him. Archie looks as if he knows more than he's saying. ARCHIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for bringing me here. I couldn't have wished for anything more. Ray recognizes there may be more behind those words than just a teenager's pleasure. But he decides not to ask any questions. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. You're welcome. Archie runs through the door in the fence and vanishes. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mann and Karin eat their country breakfasts at one and of the table, while at the other end, Annie and Ray sit in front of the bank books, ledgers, and the sheaf of bills puffed up around the paper spike. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once we fell behind in the payments, the full amount of the mortgage became due. CONTINUED     96 135 CONTINUED 135 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they own the paper, so they have the legal right to foreclose. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless we sell. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way we lose the farm. Maybe we can make it a condition of the sale that they keep the field up. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. They're buying up single farms all around us, make it one big farm. First thing they'll do is plow under your field. Ray just sits there, letting that sink in. CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1.36 Ray and Mann walking. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a lot of money, Ray, but maybe I could pitch in a little. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. You can put in twenty bucks for groceries. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant. Maybe the reason you were supposed to find me was so I could help you with this. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More likely it's that you're supposed to start writing again. About this. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't change the subject. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promise to publish and I'll let you chip in from your royalties. Mann's expression suddenly turns to one of indignation. CONTINUED     97 136 CONTINUED 136 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing has nothing to do with the other. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I agree with that. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not only stubborn, you're stupid. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I won't argue with. Annie emerges from the house and calls to Ray. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, that was Mark. He's coming tonight. He needs a decision tonight. CUT TO 137 THE GAME 137

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, it's J,oe Jackson's Chicago White Sox against the York Giants, now featuring rookie Archie Graham. In the stands, Mann keeps score, Karin munches on a hot dog, and Annie and Ray snuggle together to watch the game ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is so perfect here. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever I have to do to save this place, I'll do. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Suddenly, Ray snaps his head to the side, as one does to pick up a-distant sound. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here. They look and see Mark's car heading up the gravel lane. He parks the car at the edge of the field, and the game stops as he walks right across it, completely mindless of the players. Since he doesn't see any of them, a few actually have to move out of his way. He approaches the bottom of the bleachers. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're interrupting the game, . Mark. CONTINUED     98 137 CONTINUED 137

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark shakes his head sadly at the thought that these otherwise sensible relations have lost their minds. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, it's time'to put away our little fantasies and come down to earth. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a fantasy, Mark. They're real. Mark obviously do.esn't see anyone on the field. MARK (EMPHATICALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's real? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoeless Joe Jackson. The White Sox. The Giants. (TO MANN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't see any of it. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's that? Babe Ruth? Ray smiles, savoring the moment. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, it's Terence Mann. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, how do you? I'm Michael Jackson. (TO RAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, we have to settle this thing right now. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not selling you my home. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no money, you've got a stack of bills to choke a pig, and come fall, you've got no crop to sell. But I have a deal to offer you that will allow you to stay on this land. This has Ray's attention. Mark climbs the bleachers to stand closer to him. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, we don't have to sell the farm. But no one pays her any attention. All eyes are on Mark. CONTINUED     99 137 CONTINUED (2) 137 MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us buy you out, and we'll leave the house. You can live in it rent free as long as you want. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the baseball field? MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what this land is worth? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over $2200 an acre. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you must realize we cannot keep a useless baseball diamond in the middle of rich farmland. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No deal, Mark. We're staying. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to go. MARK (EXPLODES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're virtually bankrupt, and I'm offering you a way to keep your home because I love my sister! I've got partners who don't give a damn about you, and they're ready to foreclose right now! KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, we don't have to sell the farm. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin, please! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. They all turn to Karin. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will come. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What people, sweetheart? CONTINUED     100 137 CONTINUED (3) 137 KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From all over. They'll just decide to take a vacation, see, and they'll come to Iowa City, and they'll think it's really boring, so they'll take a drive. And they'll drive down our road, and they'll see the lights and they'll think it's really pretty. Ray, Annie, and Mann listen with wonder, to this vision. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the people in the cars? They'll drive up and they'll want to pay us, like buying a ticket. Mark looks at them all as if they're crazy. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening to this seriously, are you? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would anybody pay money to come here? Karin looks at her Uncle mark as if he were a simpleton. KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To watch the game. And it'll be just like when they were little kids a long time ago, and it was summertime, and they'll watch the game and .remember what it was like. Ray and Annie couldn't be prouder of their daughter than they are right now. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is she talking about? ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's talking about people seeing their memories... touching their past. RAY (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will come. CONTINUED     101 137 CONTINUED (4) 137 ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be like one of those tiny, French restaurants that have no sign. You find it by instinct. They'll be drawn. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, this is all fascinating, but the fact remains that you don't have the money to bring the mortgage up to date, so you still have to sell. I'm sorry, but you have no choice. He produces a document and hands it to Ray with a pen. Ra looks at it. He doesn't know what to do. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray... Ray looks at Mann. 138 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: speaks now as he has not spoken for many years: as Terenc Mann, master of words, spellbinder. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will come, Ray. They'll come to Iowa for reasons they can't even fathom. They'll turn up your driveway, not knowing for sure why they're doing it, and arrive at your door, innocent as children, longing for the past. 'Of course we won't mind if you look around,' you'll say. 'It's only twenty dollars per person.' And they'll pass over the money without even looking at it. For it is money they have, and peace they lack. 139 MARK 139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pushes the papers. forward. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just sign the papers, Ray. 140 MANN 140

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is not one to give up. CONTINUED     102 140 CONTINUED 140 MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll walk out to the bleachers and sit in shirtsleeves in the perfect evening, or they'll find they have reserved seats somewhere in the grandstand or along one of the baselines -- wherever they sat when they were children and cheered their heroes. They'll watch the game, and it will be as if they'd dipped themselves in magic waters. The memories will be so thick they'll have to brush them away from their faces. 141 MASTER 141

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spellbound, Ray has put the papers down. Mark picks them up again. He is battling Mann for Ray's attention. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Tomorrow morning, when the bank opens, they will foreclose. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will come, Ray. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're broke, Ray. Sell now or lose everything. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one constant through all the years, Ray, has been baseball. America has rolled by like an`army of steamrollers. It's been erased like a blackboard, rebuilt, and erased again. But baseball has marked the time. This field, this В° game... it's a piece of our past. It reminds us of all that once was good. And that could be again. People will come. People will most definitely come. Mann has moved everyone (but Mark) with the beauty of his words, and the passion in his.voice. Behind him, the assembled ballplayers respectfully applaud. BUCK WEAVER (TEARY-EYED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was beautiful... The other players nod, also teary-eyed. CONTINUED     103 141 CONTINUED 141 BUCK WEAVER (SINCERELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .fuckin' beautiful. The players on either side of him jab his ribs with their elbows, but Mann, Ray and Annie laugh with pleasure. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. You will lose everything and you will be evicted. Ray looks at the paper with dread. He looks at Shoeless Joe and the players. He looks at his family. Then he turns back to Mark. It's decision time. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not signing. Mark shakes his head sadly. Annie hugs Ray. The players breathe a great sigh of relief. Mann smiles. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray... Ray looks up at Mann, who, with a gentle tilt of the head directs Ray's attention to the house. Ray looks behind hi toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: RAY'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: have parked in front of the house. More are coming quietl down the driveway. Dozens of cars. Cars with out-of-state license plates. Some people,have gotten out of their cars and wait patiently. One or two families sit on their hoods, or hav set up picnic dinners on their station wagons' tailgates. 143 THE BLEACHERS 143

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, Annie, Karin and Mann are deeply happy -- but not terribly surprised -- to see these people. RAY (SING-SONG)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're he-re. Mark looks at the house and then back at Ray. NARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's here? CONTINUED     104 143 CONTINUED 143 RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge) You don't see those cars? All those people? MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this, you son of a bitch! There's no cars, no people... KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Mark, I can see them. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all can. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. You're all bat-shit crazy! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your language, Mark. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You build a baseball field in the middle of nowhere, you sit around here and stare at nothing --- KARIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not nothing. Mark grabs Karin's arm and pulls her to her feet as if sh were "Exhibit A." MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've turned your daughter into a goddamn moron! RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off her. Ray rises threateningly, and Mark turns toward him. In so doing, he twists little Karin off balance. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help you, goddamnit! In that split second, they hear a strangled gasp, and see Karin falling forward from the top row of the bleachers. RA Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin!!     105 144 KARIN 144

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hot dog flies off, the bun and wiener separating in midair. One small sandal bounces end over end and lands at the foot of the bleacher. It takes forever for her bod to come down with a sickening thud on the hard green boar of one of the bottom rows. 145 THE OTHERS 145

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rush down to where she lies, face up. Ray is first, but he does not know what to do. Annie and Mann hover. Mark is horror-stricken, but no one knows what to do. MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I'm sorry...Annie...I didn't mean to... Karin is unconscious, and seems to be fighting for breath Ray and Annie's eyes meet in anguish. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we move her? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the car. 146 ANNIE 146

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: springs for the house. The tourists by their cars watch quietly. ANNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a doctor? A nurse? Any of you? They sadly shake their heads no. Annie races inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the White Sox players stand by the left field fence, staring silently. MANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long? RA Y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its a twenty-minute drive. Mann winces. He knows that could be fatal. Ray kneels by Karin. Her nose and one side of her face have been scrape by the fall. Blood starts to trickle from her nose, acros her cheek and down her neck. She is becoming bluer and he cough is faint, as though she is in another room. CONTINUED     106 147 CONTINUED 147

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes off his $300 pale-green velvet corduroy jacket and is wordlessly holding it out to Ray. Ray takes the jacket and covers Karin gently. Karin is getting paler, bluer, and her breathing more strained and distant. RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karin... Then, without reason, Ray slowly turns toward the field. The White Sox stand near him by the fence, the Giants sta around their bench. All except one: young Archie Graham. 148 ARCHIE GRAHAM 148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: has noticed the'commotion in the bleachers, and he starts to lope across the field. 149 BLEACHERS 149

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie has pulled the car over and honks. Ray holds up his hand to her to wait. His eyes are on young Archie Graham.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ARCHIE GRAHAM
dialogues.text: 3.50 As Graham gets closer, his features begin to change, and his step slows. He reaches the end of the fence -- around which no player can pass -- and when he emerges from the shadows on the bleachers side, he is no longer young Moonlight Graham, the ballplayer of long ago...but Doc Graham, the old man from Chisholm, Minnesota. His basebal glove has turned into a black doctor's bag. 151 THE BLEACHERS 151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Doc Graham approaches. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we got here? RAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fell. Doc kneels beside her and instantly knows what is wrong. DOC GRAHAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This child's choking to death. CONTINUED     107 151 CONTINUED 151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks her up with one hand under her shoulders and the other under her knees, seats himself on the bleachers, an turns her face down. Supporting her chest with one hand, he delivers a series of sharp blows between her shoulder blades with the heel of his other hand. Annie honks again. Ray waves her to him.
